thread.title: Queensland Symphony Orchestra snares talents of Alondra de la Parra
thread.title_full: Queensland Symphony Orchestra snares talents of Alondra de la Parra

author: Nance Haxton
title: Queensland Symphony Orchestra snares talents of Alondra de la Parra
text:
Map: QLD 
In what many classical music buffs consider a major coup for the sunshine state, the Queensland Symphony Orchestra has snared the talents of one of the world's most acclaimed conductors as its first music director. 
Alondra de la Parra will tonight grace Brisbane's Concert Hall commemorating the 70th anniversary of the orchestra, with a performance of the same work the orchestra played at its debut. 
De la Parra may be small in stature, but her presence on the towering Concert Hall stage in Brisbane is enormous. 
Her long limbs dance around the podium, and her facial expressions rise and fall as she gracefully guides the orchestra through the subtleties and climaxes of Mahler's Titan. 
"I'm very keen on the conductor being a visual coefficient of the music so if you can only see the conductor and you can't hear anything you should know what piece of music it is," she said. 
"There are so many areas a conductor needs to develop the ear, the ability to rehearse, to talk to the audience, to analyse the score. 
"The mathematical part of the brain and the expressive and instinctive part of the brain they both have to be functioning and that's really hard. 
"So I think it's a process that gets better and better with time and it seasons as you grow older." De la Parra breaking the mould Photo: Mexican conductor Alondra de la Parra. (Supplied: Queensland Symphony Orchestra.) 
De la Parra holds the distinction of being the first Mexican woman to conduct in New York City, and is an official cultural ambassador of Mexico. 
She hopes being a female conductor in what is a highly competitive field will one day no longer be an issue. 
"I always had very good ears and was very good at organising people and my father was the one who told me why don't you conduct — you should become a conductor," she said. 
"I was 13 and when he explained why it clicked and I thought that's not a bad idea. 
"I think things have changed already in my personal journey — it's been such a difficult process but not because I am a woman necessarily, mostly because it's just such a hard profession anyway. 
De la Parra has led more than 70 orchestras around the globe, but it is Brisbane she is now proud to call home for the next year. 
"Everything's really easy here," she said. 
"Where we come from, Mexico City, which is a great city, but it's so humongous and and there's so much traffic. This is such a contrast. 
"Have you heard the orchestra? It's such a good group, such an amazing level of talent. 
"It was love at first sight with the orchestra and with the town. 
"Of course it's really far away but that's the only downside."
